column1: The American Indians called the area "Ahdawagam"
column2: meaning "Two-sided Rapids". Although Europeans began to settle this area in the 1830s
column3: Wisconsin Rapids has been known by this name only since 1920. Prior to that
column4: the community was divided by the Wisconsin River
column5: with the west side incorporated as Centralia and the east side as Grand Rapids. The two cities merged in 1900
column6: with the entire community taking the name Grand Rapids. The name was changed in 1920 to avoid mail and other goods from being misdirected to the much better known Grand Rapids

column2: Wisconsin Rapids is also an important locale for the cranberry industry. Wisconsin Rapids is the corporate home of the international educational software company
column3: Renaissance Learning
column4: Inc. as well as other national and global companies.From its founding in 1894
column5: Wisconsin Rapids was home to the corporate headquarters of Consolidated Papers
column7: which was acquired by the Finnish company Stora Enso in early 2000. In 2007
column8: NewPage Corporation acquired the paper production facility. In 2015
column9: Verso Corporation acquired the mill. Verso continues its presence in the area with a paper mill that houses two paper machines and a kraft pulp mill.  In June of 2020
column10: Verso announced the closing of their paper mill for at least two months
column11: with the resulting loss of 900 jobs.

column1: Wisconsin Rapids is served by Wisconsin Rapids Public Schools. Lincoln High School is the local public high school
column2: serving grades 9 through 12. Assumption High School is a private Catholic high school. River Cities High School is an alternative to the local high schools. The city has two middle schools
column3: Wisconsin Rapids Area Middle School (grades 6–8) and Central Oaks (Virtual) Academy (6-8). East Junior High was a junior high school for grades 8-9 before it closed after the 2017–2018 school year.Good Shepherd Lutheran School (1-8th grade) and St. Paul's Lutheran School (3K-8th grade) are two grade schools of the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod in Wisconsin Rapids.

column1: Wisconsin Rapids has several local parks
column3: Gaynor Park
column4: and Lyon Park. There is also a skate park. The state water-skiing championships are held at Lake Wazeecha every year and the national BMX Bandit cycling championships are held at the Central Wisconsin BMX velodrome.

column1: The Wisconsin Rapids Aquatic Center opened in July 2020 and features several pools and other recreational facilities including a tennis court

column1: The Wisconsin Rapids Riverkings are a hockey team who is a member of the United States Premier Hockey League and won the Midwest Elite Championship in the 2016 - 2017 season. The Riverkings currently play their home games at the SWCRC.

The Wisconsin Rapids Rafters are a collegiate summer baseball team who are a member of the Northwoods League. The Rafters won the league championship in 2016. They currently play their home games at Witter Field.
The Alexander House is a museum to the history of the Nekoosa Edwards Paper Company (NEPCO)
column2: and also hosts art exhibits. The building is the former home of the Alexander Family
column3: which ran the Nekoosa Edwards Paper Company.

column1: The South Wood County Historical Corporation Museum houses multiple exhibits covering the history of the South Wood County area. The building is the former Witter family home.
There is a prairie chicken sanctuary at the Buena Vista Wildlife Reservation
column2: and every year the Prairie Chicken Festival is held.

column1: The Souper Snow Sculpture Spectacular that takes place every February is one of the largest snow sculpture competitions in the country by numbers of sculptures.
The Grand Affair Arts Festival takes place in September of each year.
